So in the long-term plan in year two, we forecast a rates rise of 4.4% and we're proposing in this annual plan a rise of 4.3. That 4.3 is what each individual ratepayer will pay on average. These capital projects are largely where we get some timing issues. Occasionally we will bring a project forward, more often it's deferred for sometimes as mundane a reason as the weather.  So, adjustments to our capital work paid programme. And it is basically all timing. Te Ameru Te Porongia via Ngaroto has been deferred only because of the issues in getting affected landholders agreements, but  I'm happy to report that really substantial progress has been made in the last two or three months with that. And we have a report coming to committee next Tuesday, I believe, detailing that. So our fingers are all crossed that we're going to get some actual work done this coming summer. Yeah, the other  major thing affecting the Te Aumutu district, well the whole district actually, is the recycling, targeted recycling rate and the high cost that contamination of recycling has had to be addressed.  It's not very disappointing, actually, but it's just a fact of life, and we will do education programs, et cetera, to try and minimize that, but there we are. And also, yes, urban mobility. In a nutshell, Waka Kotahi's run out of money, so they haven't been able to co-fund this program, but this is a deferral. It will happen.  and it needs to happen. Improving the walking and cycling infrastructure of our towns is really important. So, key projects coming up. As I said, the cycleway. At Te Arawa, the initial design phase will happen. So there is some time being spent in that area. We have, yeah, ongoing growth for residential and industrial development. And that's where the biggest deferral of capital expenditure has taken place, actually, in Cambridge and in their big  residential developments. It's just a developer-led deferral, effectively. Cambridge Wastewater Treatment Plant is a massive project, very expensive, and it has to be in place no later than 25, 26 from memory. So it is urgent as well. And the Waipā Community Spatial Plan, this is a  a huge undertaking, but will form the basis for this district for the next 30 plus years. Getting this done properly, it's going to be transformational for the district. It will turn us into a truly strategy-led  district and, you know, will have great benefits. I think probably a lot of people aren't understanding how crucial this can be to  not only the district as a whole, but all the groups that are involved in it. text: Thanks Ange. Kia ora everyone. I'm going to try and share my screen. Can you see? The table I've shared hopefully. Yep, cool. So we thought it'd be useful to take you through our plan changes work program. It's growing and expanding.  And there's some that might be of interest to the community board. So I'll just run through this. It is in the agenda. So the first one is what we're calling Plan Change 26. And I think Andrew alluded to it in his response on the annual plan. So this is the one that the government said to all tier one councils that we must do a plan change to permit up to three houses, up to three storeys in all residential zones.  So it's pretty big, it's blindsided all tier one councils, we are a tier one council. And so we've got it in a work programme now, it's called Plan Change 26. And what it means is all residential zones in Cambridge, Te Awamutu and Kihikihi, because Kihikihi is within Te Awamutu urban boundary. Under the plan change, we are required as a default to intensify within those residential zones. We do have the ability to  have some exclusions in there. And we're trying to understand what that looks like. It's a pretty high bar to get exclusions in there. We're doing quite a bit of work behind the scenes to get that done. So that must be notified by the 20th of August. And on the date of notification, those rules come into immediate effect. So it's quite an unusual plan change. The government's really pushing councils to, I guess, promote intensification. There's some obvious concerns around what it means for infrastructure.  erosion of the urban design and amenity. And so all councils who've had this, that we need to respond to, have expressed some concerns back to ministries, the Ministry of Housing, Urban Development and MFE about what it might mean for us. So we've got that one. The next one is Plan Change 21. It's a companion one, and we will always plan to do this. So this is a council plan change. It was intended to intensify  general, and what we're doing now is we split 26 and 21. So 21, it looks at enabling affordable housing and mechanisms for doing that. It looks at strengthening urban design across the district and also looks at two growth cells. So there's C11, which is a growth cell on the outskirts of Cambridge, and there's T6, which is a growth cell between Kehekehi and Te Wanamutu opposite the golf course.  So T6 is currently zoned large lot residential. We've got an independent consultant to look at whether there's opportunity for intensifying any of the growth cells. And his recommendation was that we should look at residential in the T6 growth cell. So the proposal there is to look at the opportunity to change that from existing large lot residential to standard density residential. So quite a lot of work involved in that.  At the moment, that provides for about 400 large lots, and some of them are already being developed. If it was full residential across the whole zone, which is a little bit unrealistic, then it would be about 2,000 additional houses. But that's unrealistic because of topography, because some of those sites have already been developed, and they are probably precluded because of their configuration from re-subdivision. So there's that one that'll be of interest. That'll be publicly notified at the same time as Plan Change 26, because we want to run them in tandem.  So 20th of August, we're looking at notifying both of those. Plan Change 17 is on the outskirts of Cambridge, Hautapu, so that's looking at some industrial zoning there. Plan Change 20, you may be interested in, that's a private plan change. The airport is looking to extend an already zoned area called the Northern Precinct, which is the northwestern end of the airport. They bought some rural land and they want to extend the zoning to allow commercial slash industrial in that area.  That will be a private one, we expect that to be lodged this month, actually, April, they said, and then it'll go through a normal process. Plan change 19 is Carter Slats, it's in Cambridge. Plan change 22 is Anchor Park, so that'll be of interest. That's on a bit of a go slow, Council owns some land there on part of Anchor Park, and we're looking at the opportunity to rezone that. Currently,  specialised industrial, rezone that to residential for more housing. But there's a bit of a process to go through and that's on a go slow at the moment. And just the other update I can provide on this since this report was presented. So it's shown, Plan Change 23, which is Papakāinga, is deferred. We now have some very clear direction to get that underway. And we're looking at reactivating that. It's been on our to-do list for quite a while, but because of the other priorities,  We just had to do a triage exercise to see what we could realistically do. So we're now looking at reactivating the public climate plan change. So as you can see, quite a full list. There are some there that will be of interest to the community board, but I thought it was worth just taking you through that and happy to answer any questions. I'll stop sharing now as well.

text: I mean, branding, it's quite interesting. Branding a small town fails 85% of the time. So it's not an easy thing, and,  You know, some of the reasons, I just want to, if you can bear with me for five minutes, because I think it's important that people understand what this is all about.  and why it fails 85% of the time is people misunderstand the meaning of branding for a start. So a brand is simply what do people think about it. So what we're trying to do is find out what do people think about Te Amutu. A brand is not Rosetown, that is just a tagline to support a brand.  So Te Amuru has a brand now, but it may not be the one you want to have. So you need to manage and guide it. So that's what we're trying to find out. What is Te Amuru's brand now? What do people think of Te Amuru? And the reasons why they haven't worked in the past is because there's no consultation with all the stakeholders. A brand that over promises and under delivers, it's not authentic.  Not involving younger generation. It's a missing an emotional connection. It's not daring to be different. Lack of funding and commitment. Unrealistic timeframes that result in poor processes. And a place brand not supported by policies, innovation, events, structures, investment, and actions. And you can probably argue that Rosetown isn't supported by anything like that.  And place branding that is not a top-down exercise, but will only produce the best results when it is created and maintained through a strong coalition between local government, business, civil society, and target markets. So that's what the research says is why small town branding fails. So it's not an easy task.  It's interesting to note that the South Waikato district is going through the same process, and they've got a budget of $488,000. And the mayor, Jenny Shatlock, admits that rebranding is not an easy task, as there's been a number of attempts by the council to create a district branding in the past 15 years that has not succeeded because they are not well funded or resourced. So it's not an easy thing, but I think it's worthwhile to just  to do our best at getting feedback from the residents of Te Amuru and based on that then make some assumptions about what sort of identity Te Amuru might want to have in the future.
